properties.media:imagetext:
Flying from Hongkong to Hankow
Oct.25, 1937.
Dear Family:
Am now on a trip which
promises to be a very interesting one and
so for my own amusement and to continue my long neglected family letters
"I'll write as I please."
Mr. Bond and I left Hongkong at 11:55 this morning•
We are flying
in a tri-motored Junkers operated by the Sino-German Eurasia Company.
On the 15-passenger plane with us is one Chinése gentleman,
two foreign
men and two women,
also a full load of air express including 175 lbs. of
anti-toxin consigned to the American Ambassador at Nanking•
The latter
shipment came
over from the U.S. by Pan American and 1s
carried free of
charge by all airlines concerned.
It is somewhat gratifying to one in
business - temporarily resident in China - to
see aircraft put to
good constructive use after viewing and reading about all the destructive
and cruel uses to which airplanes have lately been put in China.
Our take-off was bumpy as are most take-offs from the pocket-like
Hongkong airport surrounded by high mountains.
Climbed through low
ground haze and broken white fluffy clouds at 3000 feet and now, having
crossed infamous Bias Bay (where the Chinese pirates have given way to
the more legal but equally piratical Japs),
we are flying over Chinese
Down below are rugged brown mountains completely deforested
sides seared and torn by the
rush of mad streams born of the torrential
rains which come in the typhoon season.
In the valleys small Chinese
villages furnish shelter for the coolie farmers who cultivate every inch
of soil washed down from the mountains.
The little valleys look very
peaceful and viewing
can understand why many of our Chinese
friends have sent
their femilies "back to the country".
Those little
villages are
not worth a Japanese serial bomb - no army occupation of
country
threatened and those little villages are probably
before because the war lords are all busy and
their hordes
of Chinese soldiers through this section.
away from the coast now flying at 7000 feet - clouds
disappeared and an Arizona sky stretches from one haze covered
horizon
other.
We have not sighted any
other airplanes and I'll
be perfectly happy
if none are encountered - of either side !
that the Hankow Field - our objective - was bombed
night before
last by
Japanese planes - hangar destroyed
- three Chinese
bombers on the ground and our poor old Western Division of PAA Ford
"loaned" to the Chinese Army were all burned up.
Unfortunately,
bombers were a German made Heinkle, an Italian made Savola-Machetti (sp !)
and an American made Martin,
all badly needed by the Chinese, and among
the last of the good planes
they had left.
The pilot also says the
field is full of shell holes but all holes are clearly marked with red
flags and several runways are marked
out for safe landing areas so there
is nothing to worry about.
Bond reminds me that it is now 1:30
and that
our Chinese No.l at Hongkong sent some
lunch boxes to us, so we'll have
chow and I'll
continue this letter later on.
Later - in fact after a good lunch of fried chicken,
sandwiches,
hot coffee and
cake,
a smoke and took a
short siesta.
07e carette, *lated con
chair back, enjoyed
contained some
cold
salad
but I passed that up.
There is still some cholera in Hongkong) •
It is
now 2:30 PM and
are now about 375 miles northwest of Hongkong
-1-
